title: Israeli settlers forcibly displacing largest Palestinian Bedouin village

originalTitle: What we know about Trump's  'framework of future deal' over Greenland
title: What we know about Trump's  'framework of future deal' over Greenland
content: Denmark and Greenland have made it clear they will not relinquish sovereignty of the world's largest island.

originalTitle: Two dead and several missing in New Zealand landslides
title: Big Rains and Sliding Earth in Faraway New Zealand!
content:
Jambo, My Wonderful Friends!

Hello everyone! It's your kid-friendly news reporter here, bringing you important stories from all over the world. Today, we're going on a little trip in our minds to a beautiful country very far away, called New Zealand. It's a place with lots of green hills, sheep, and lovely beaches. But sadly, they've had some very, very big problems there because of heavy rain. Let's learn about it together, in simple words.

What Happened So Far Away?

Imagine rain, rain, and more rain! Not just a little drizzle, but huge amounts of water falling from the sky for many, many days. This happened in New Zealand, especially on a part of the country called the North Island. When too much rain falls, the ground gets very, very wet. It's like when you play with sand and water – if you add too much water, the sand becomes runny, right? The same thing happened to the earth in New Zealand.

What is a Landslide?

When the ground gets too wet and heavy, it can't hold on anymore. Then, big parts of the earth, mud, and even trees can slide down hills! This is called a landslide. It's like a giant mud slide, but it's not for playing. Landslides are very powerful and can push over houses, block roads, and cause lots of danger. In New Zealand, these landslides were very big and came down many hillsides.

Why Was It So Bad?

Because of all the rain and landslides, some people sadly got hurt. The news tells us that two people have died, and many more are missing. 'Missing' means people can't find them, and everyone is very worried. Imagine if you couldn't find your friend or family member after a big storm – it would be very scary and sad. Many homes were broken, and roads were covered in mud and rocks. One important person in New Zealand said it looked like a "war zone." This doesn't mean there was a war, but it means the damage was so big and messy, like after a big fight.

So Many Homes and Roads Broken!

The landslides didn't just move mud. They moved big rocks and trees too. People's houses, where they eat and sleep and play, were swept away or crushed. Imagine your house suddenly moving! It must be very frightening. Roads that cars use to travel were completely blocked. This means people can't drive to work, or go to the shops, or even go to school. Some towns were cut off, meaning no one could get in or out. It's a very difficult time for the people of New Zealand.

Who is Helping?

Even when sad things happen, there are always heroes! In New Zealand, many brave people are helping. These are the rescuers – like firefighters, police, and even people from the army. They are working very hard to find the missing people and help those who are stuck. They use special tools and even their hands to dig through the mud and mess. Many ordinary people are also helping their neighbours and friends, sharing food and a safe place to stay. It shows how strong people can be when they work together.

Did You Know? Fun Facts!

* **Did you know?** New Zealand is made up of two big islands and many smaller ones! It's in a part of the world called Oceania. * **Did you know?** There are more sheep than people in New Zealand! Baa! * **Did you know?** Heavy rain and storms like this sometimes get a special name, like a cyclone or a hurricane. They bring very strong winds too, not just rain. * **Did you know?** It's always important to listen to grown-ups during bad weather. They know how to keep you safe!

What Can We Learn?

This sad story from New Zealand teaches us a few things. First, nature can be very powerful. We must respect the weather. Second, it shows how important it is for people to help each other when times are tough. Even though New Zealand is far away, we can send kind thoughts to the people there, hoping they stay safe and find their missing loved ones. We can also remember that it's good to be prepared for heavy rain, even where we live.

Sending Our Love

Let's all think about the people in New Zealand. We hope the rain stops, the sun shines again, and everyone can start rebuilding their homes and lives. It will take time, but with brave helpers and strong communities, they will get through this. Stay safe, my friends, and always be kind to each other! Your kid reporter, over and out!
summary: Heavy rains in New Zealand caused big landslides, sadly killing two people and leaving many missing, as homes and roads were destroyed, but brave helpers are working hard to find everyone.
whyMatters: This story matters because it shows how powerful nature can be and how important it is for people to help each other when bad things happen, even in countries far away.

originalTitle: UK holds off joining Trump's Board of Peace over Putin concerns
title: UK holds off joining Trump's Board of Peace over Putin concerns
content: Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper says the Russian president has shown no commitment to peace in Ukraine.

originalTitle: 'Ridiculous amount of games' - has Haaland played too much football?
title: 'Ridiculous amount of games' - has Haaland played too much football?
content: Erling Haaland made a blistering start to the season but that prolific run of form has ground to a halt with only one goal in his past eight games.

originalTitle: 'Unique' Rogers looks to prove worth for Villa & England
title: 'Unique' Rogers looks to prove worth for Villa & England
content: Morgan Rogers says he "can be anything" - while the Aston Villa star is talking about his positional flexibility, rather than boasting about his quality, his confidence is well-placed.

title: Would Man Utd 2008 really 'batter' Arsenal 2026?
content: After being challenged by Theo Walcott, Wayne Rooney said the Manchester United side of 2008 would "batter" the current Arsenal team.
